title.narrative: Humanitarian assistance to conflict affected communities in Rakhine State

description.narrative:
This project supports life-saving health care and protection activities, specifically gender-based violence (GBV) prevention and response, to conflict affected communities who face acute humanitarian needs in Sittwe Township, Rakhine State.
The project is designed to strengthen IRC’s current emergency responses in Sittwe Township, and will address acute health and protection needs. The escalation of conflict on 25 August 2017 and additional displacement from northern Rakhine to Sittwe Townships of an estimated 19,055 persons has impacted service delivery to IDP camps and conflict-affected villages. The provision of adequate health and GBV services, which was strained prior to the current crisis, has been further challenged by increased caseloads and restricted access, as well as heightened levels of need among conflict affected communities.
Through this project IRC will support access to Basic Primary Health Care (PHC), Reproductive Health Care services (RHC) and improved emergency referral pathways through mobile health clinics across four locations Dar Paing and West San Pya IDP camps and Thar Yar Kone and Thae Chaung villages. These sites have been selected based on large beneficiary numbers and high patient consultation rate as well as to ensure a conflict sensitive approach. IRC will deploy 2 mobile health teams to provide primary and reproductive health care in static clinic sites. This action will also establish and support the capacity of Community Health Workers (CHWs) to provide basic health care, with a focus on integrated community case management (iCCM) for under 5 years in the targeted sites. Strengthened emergency referral will support at-risk communities to better access higher levels of emergency care, including emergency obstetrics care. IRC will also support responses to emergencies, outbreak alerts and immunization requests.
The project will also work to address key barriers for women, girls and people with disabilities to safely access health and GBV services within a tense security environment through conflict community engagement and service delivery at the community level. The project is designed to leverage IRC’s current emergency responses in Sittwe Township, and will address acute health and protection needs. This project is designed to address the increased acute humanitarian needs and vulnerabilities through a conflict sensitive programming approach.
As currently secured funding will end in the coming months, this project will come at a critical time to address key humanitarian needs now as well as anticipated gaps in early 2018, in line with the Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) and call for proposals. IRC will continue to support and train Community Health Workers (CHWs) from the targeted villages to strengthen local response and provision of basic health services.
